newsitem.title: GERMANY: Dresdner eyes possibly higher dividend.
newsitem.headline: Dresdner eyes possibly higher dividend.

text.p: Germany's second largest commercial bank Dresdner Bank AG said on Thursday that it expected its 1997 profits to allow it to pay a shareholder friendly dividend and add to its reserves.
In its annual report released ahead of Thursday's news conference the bank said German banks would be facing difficult and competitive conditions in 1997.
To strengthen its competitive position and safeguard its earnings power, Dresdner said it would have to invest during the year and said loan loss provisioning would remain stable but high.
"Against this background, we expect a profit in 1997 that will enable us both to pay an appropriate dividend and continue strengthening our reserves," group said in the annual report.
For 1996 Dresdner paid a dividend of 1.45 marks (84 cents) plus an anniversary bonus of 10 pfennigs per share.
The bank also reported that its 1996 net profit had climbed 30.7 percent to 1.58 billion marks ($ = 1.722 German Marks)

Dresdner Bank also said that operating profit after provisions totalled 2.86 billion marks after 1.99 billion marks a year ago. Group loan loss provisions totalled 1.1 billion marks after 1.075 billion marks.
